Situation1: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: The regular weekly Shabbat service is approaching.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, my phone buzzing with messages from the contractor. The steel delivery was delayed, and if I didn’t resolve it today, the entire project would fall behind. My mind raced with calculations and contingency plans, but in the back of my mind, another responsibility pressed in. Shabbat was approaching, and I hadn’t yet prepared my sermon. The congregation expected inspiration, guidance, and presence. I glanced at the clock—just a few hours left before sundown. My heart pounded as I weighed the urgency of the construction schedule against the spiritual needs of my community. Both roles demanded my full attention, and I felt myself pulled in two directions, the expectations of architect and rabbi colliding within me.
